text: Good developers write code; great developers refactor it.
The best debugger? Console.log. The second best? Rubber duck.
Learn one thing deeply, and you'll be able to learn anything else more easily.
Your future self will thank you for writing clear, commented code today.
Chasing the latest tech trends is fun, but mastering the fundamentals is essential.
Automate the boring stuff‚Äîyour future projects will thank you.
Reading code is just as important as writing it. Dive into open source.
A well-named variable is worth a thousand comments.
Start with a plan, but don‚Äôt be afraid to refactor.
Every bug is a chance to learn something new.
Coding is 90% thinking and 10% typing.
The best projects start with a solid folder structure.
Version control: because undo can only take you so far.
Your code should be as readable as your morning newspaper.
Keep your dependencies up to date‚Äîfuture you will thank you.
Whitespace isn't just for aesthetics‚Äîit's for readability.
Code is like humor. When you have to explain it, it's bad.
Consistent code style isn‚Äôt just nice‚Äîit‚Äôs necessary.
Remember: shortcuts make code easier to write, not necessarily easier to read.
Always have a backup of your backup. Paranoia pays off.
A little bit of testing can prevent a lot of debugging.
Don‚Äôt fear the command line‚Äîembrace it.
Measure twice, cut once. The same goes for refactoring.
Writing code is great, but don‚Äôt forget to write documentation too.
Commenting on your code is like leaving a note for future developers.
If you‚Äôre not learning something new every day, you‚Äôre not pushing hard enough.
Don‚Äôt reinvent the wheel, unless you‚Äôre just curious.
Coding is like a craft‚Äîthe more you practice, the better you get.
Complexity kills productivity. Keep it simple.
Every line of code should tell a story, and the ending should be clear.
Great system design is about balancing trade-offs, not perfection.
Design for scale from day one, but don't over-engineer.
Simplicity in design is harder to achieve, but always worth it.
Every system has bottlenecks‚Äîyour job is to identify and manage them.
Think about failure modes before they happen, not after.
Load balancing is the key to handling high traffic with grace.
Caching: because not everything needs to be fetched every time.
Redundancy is your insurance against unexpected downtime.
Stateless systems are easier to scale, but harder to manage.
Microservices: Divide and conquer your system‚Äôs complexity.
APIs should be designed with both simplicity and future-proofing in mind.
Design for failure; build for resilience.
Your system is only as strong as its weakest point.
Data consistency vs. availability‚Äîknow when to choose one over the other.
In system design, less is often more.
Plan for data growth from the start‚Äîyour future self will thank you.
Horizontal scaling beats vertical scaling when in doubt.
Monitoring and observability are essential, not optional.
A well-designed system handles edge cases gracefully.
Choose the right database for the job‚ÄîSQL isn‚Äôt always the answer.
Security should be baked into your system design, not added later.
Design with clear SLAs in mind‚Äîyour users will appreciate it.
Every system has trade-offs; understand them before making decisions.
Latency kills user experience; optimize for speed.
Keep data close to where it‚Äôs needed‚Äîgeographic distribution matters.
Design for maintainability; your codebase will outlast you.
A good system design anticipates change and accommodates it.
Data integrity is non-negotiable‚Äîdesign with this in mind.
High availability is expensive, but downtime costs more.
